resources: RadicallyDifferent Welcome to Radically Different! Read the introduction Check out the Library of Radicals Match radicals to Hanzi Plan an efficient road trip Build a Hanzi puzzle Welcome to this interactive instructional of reading Chinese! Thank you for joining me. This is intended for people that are currently or have previously studied written Chinese. Please consider looking over the radical library and games afterwards. In 1916 a Swiss linguist, Ferdinand de Saussure said, “Time changes all things; there is no reason why language should escape this universal law.” Any introduction to Chinese characters or Hanzi, will explain that the first were pictographs. As time went on, life changed for the people speaking and writing this language. Their ideas and writing changed. Some things that used to make sense written down, no longer do and as Chinese language learners, we need to accept this. But fear not! Hanzi can actually be very easy for visual learners if you learn to imagine the parts. These parts are known as radicals. If you can learn to break down “complicated” words in any other language, Chinese is no different.\ 女+马=妈 nv+ma=ma The woman whose name sounds like “horse” (ma) is the mother (ma). Not all words are this simple, but enough are that getting comfortable with beginning Chinese can set up your foundation for intermediate level. Please look up the radical library with 85 different introductory radicals to get you started. Once you’re comfortable there, try some games to see if you’ve gotten the hang of it. Note: we’re going to focus on radicals- hence the app name. I will be supplying you with tips and tricks to learn them and I hope you find them as useful as I did. %s %s %s %s %s %s %s %s %s %s %s radical strokes traditional variant meaning mnemonic example note
